awd_titl_txt: A Distributed Learning Environment for the Mathematics of Climate and Sustainability
awd_abstract_narration:
The research project focus will be on the mathematics needed for understanding our climate, its impacts and will help address the pressing issues of adaptation and sustainability in light of inevitable changes. Through this program, four cohorts of students will be trained in the mathematics underlying the all-important societal and scientific issues emanating from climate and sustainability. This will span a five year period and encompass four intensive week-long summer camps. Each cohort will consist of seven graduate and three undergraduate students. They will be trained in collaborative team-work that will prepare them well for a career in any scientific endeavor involving mathematical investigation. Each year will include online training to prepare the students for the summer camp and ongoing focus research groups during the subsequent academic year, during which time the students will work on concrete research problems.

A new approach to both graduate and undergraduate student research training in applied mathematics is envisioned. The program will be based around yearly cycles in which a new cohort of students will be drawn from a national pool of applicants each year. The students will be brought through the program and trained in critical research and professional skills needed in the modern world of collaborative and interdisciplinary research. The year-long activities will be built around an intensive summer camp that kicks off the program for each student and ongoing web-based groups through which much of the skill-building and mentoring will take place. The effort is a partnership between the Mathematics and Climate Research Network (MCRN) and the American Institute of Mathematics (AIM). MCRN has considerable experience in building a web-active community that keeps a large geographically dispersed group engaged throughout the year and it will be the host environment for this effort. AIM will provide the institutional framework as well. This award was co-funded by the NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program.  The NRT Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training.

por.por_cntn:
Mathematics is a key player in both understanding and addressing climate change. The Mathematics and Climate Research Network (MCRN) has empowered a new generation of mathematical scientists to develop the knowledge and skills to address this major societal challenge by applying their mathematical talent. This has been achieved through a succession of summer schools and collaborative workshops coupled with ongoing research group activity throughout the year, both through traditional research groups within institutions and collaborative groups distributed across the network.. The emphasis in the research groups has been on teamwork through which each member appreciates the complementary talents and skills of other members. Since the individuals in the network are distributed across the country, the project has leveraged and developed online platforms to great effect. The teams have included students from undergraduate through advanced graduate, and postdoctoral scholars as well as senior faculty leaders. The vertical integration of the groups has been a particularly successful part of the project.

Summer schools on climate and sustainability were held in 2018, 2019 and 2023. These led to projects, and in turn papers and presentations, on abrupt change in climate systems, resilience to disturbances, specific systems like the polar vortex and El Niño, vegetation loss, and ocean circulation. The incorporation of observational data into models has been a particular focus, especially for novel underlying computational systems. In summer 2020, in a collaboration with the American Institute of Mathematics, the members of this project developed a rapid response summer school to the COVID crisis. This fully online school, spread over two months, engaged almost fifty students in projects aimed at understanding and mitigating the spread of COVID. This school led to a number of publications ranging from a study of the effect of lockdown on atmospheric carbon to one that used a novel approach combining data and transmission models to understand disparities in COVID transmission , death rates, and testing across racial and ethnic groups.

One outcome of the project has been the design of an educational environment that is particularly successful in training students in skills needed for a range of careers. It has further been notably successful in attracting women students as well as members of underrepresented minority groups.

A new MCRN leadership has emerged of early-career mathematicians. Their plans have grown out of this project and extend some of its most successful elements, including mentoring chains and online research groups, and introduce new ones, such as safe spaces for the discussion of new ideas and publication of a collection of curriculum materials. Most of these new leaders were students trained under this award and a predecessor project that laid the foundation for MCRN. A photo is attached of the community workshop in Portland (May, 2023) that brings this to life.

The challenge to develop mathematics for climate and sustainability is daunting. Mathematics departments in academia around the US have been slow to pick up the need for dedicated training, both from a general skills and specific knowledge viewpoint. The goal of this project was to fill this gap by training students in a national network that crossed institutional boundaries. What has resulted is a model not only for efforts in climate mathematics, but for other emerging areas of pressing scientific and societal importance that fall outside the traditional purview of a mathematics department.
